name: Abdul Sattar Edhi
intro: Abdul Sattar Edhi was a Pakistani humanitarian who founded the Edhi Foundation, which operates the world's largest volunteer ambulance network.
description: Starting with a single van, his organization grew to provide free medical care, orphanages, and nursing homes that have saved and supported over 1 million people, including over 25,000 abandoned infants placed in his "Jhoolas" or cradles.
motive: Edhi was motivated by a philosophy of "humanitarianism above religion" and a simple, ascetic lifestyle dedicated entirely to the service of the poor such that his dying wish was to have his organs transplanted to those in need.

name: Fe del Mundo
intro: Fe del Mundo was a Filipino pediatrician who laid the foundations for her country's child healthcare system and the first woman to be admitted as a student at Harvard Medical School.
description: She founded the first pediatric hospital in the Philippines and spent eight decades revolutionizing rural healthcare, providing medical services to hundreds of thousands of children and pioneering an inexpensive incubator made of bamboo which could operate without electricity.
motive: Del Mundo was motivated by a desire to bring modern medicine to the remote areas of her country where children were dying from preventable causes, particularly after the death of her younger sister Elisa, who had made known her desire to become a doctor for the poor.

name: Tom Catena
intro: Tom Catena is an American physician and Catholic lay missionary who has been the only permanent surgeon for a population of nearly 1 million people in the war-torn Nuba Mountains of Sudan since 2008.
description: Operating in a hospital that is frequently targeted by government bombers, he performs up to 1,000 surgeries per year and treats everything from shrapnel wounds to leprosy and malnutrition on a salary of $350/month while on call 24/7.
motive: Catena is motivated by his Catholic faith, in particular St. Francis of Assisi, the belief that every life is of equal value, and the vocational call to serve those whom the rest of the world has forgotten.

name: Catherine Hamlin
intro: Catherine Hamlin was an Australian OB/GYN who spent over 60 years in Ethiopia providing obstetric fistula repair surgery to impoverished women suffering from devastating childbirth injuries.
description: She co-founded the Addis Ababa Fistula Hospital, which has provided free, life-restoring surgery to over 60,000 women who had been rendered incontinent and ostracized by their communities due to childbirth injuries.
motive: Hamlin was motivated by a strong Christian faith and an immense compassion for the most marginalized, forgotten women in the world.

name: Hugh Thompson Jr.
intro: Hugh Thompson Jr. was a U.S. Army helicopter pilot during the Vietnam War who intervened to stop the My Lai Massacre.
description: He landed his helicopter between fleeing Vietnamese civilians and pursuing American soldiers, ordering his door gunner to fire on his own troops if they continued the slaughter—an act that directly saved at least 11 unarmed civilians.
motive: Thompson was motivated by a fundamental sense of humanity and a refusal to remain a silent witness to what he recognized as clear war crimes and "pure, premeditated murder."

name: Sister Rosemary Connelly
intro: Sister Rosemary Connelly is a Catholic nun who transformed the care of individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities at Misericordia in Chicago.
description: Under her leadership, Misericordia expanded from a small facility to a 31-acre campus that provides a residential community and vocational programs for over 600 residents, focusing on life's possibilities rather than limitations.
motive: Connelly was motivated by the belief that every person, regardless of their disability, has an inherent right to live a life of dignity, purpose, and community belonging.

name: Ruth Coker Burks
intro: Ruth Coker Burks, known as the "Cemetery Angel," was a young woman in Arkansas who cared for hundreds of people dying of AIDS during the height of the 1980s crisis.
description: She personally cared for over 1,000 patients who had been abandoned by their own families and healthcare providers, and she used her own family burial plots to provide a final resting place for over 40 people whose remains no one else would claim—despite facing ostracism and KKK cross-burnings.
motive: Burks was motivated by simple human empathy ("just trying to do what was right") and a refusal to leave others to die alone—despite having herself been abandoned as a 5-year-old by her mother after her father died.

name: Bishop Paride Taban
intro: Bishop Paride Taban is a South Sudanese prelate who founded the Holy Trinity Peace Village in Kuron to foster reconciliation among warring tribes.
description: His village provides a neutral sanctuary where over 3,000 people from different ethnic backgrounds live, work, and learn together, successfully ending cattle raiding and conflict in a region previously devastated by civil war.
motive: Taban was motivated by a lifelong quest for peace in his war-torn country and the belief that peace is not the absence of war, but the presence of love and brotherhood.

name: Carl Lutz
intro: Carl Lutz was a Swiss diplomat in Budapest who conducted the largest civilian rescue operation of WWII.
description: He issued "letters of protection" to over 62,000 Jews, representing half of the Jewish population that survived in Budapest, and he placed 76 buildings under Swiss extraterritorial protection to serve as safe houses.
motive: Lutz was motivated by a strong Methodist faith and the conviction that his diplomatic immunity was a tool to be used for the moral necessity of saving human lives.

name: Irena Sendler
intro: Irena Sendler was a Polish social worker and member of the underground resistance who specialized in smuggling Jewish children out of the Warsaw Ghetto.
description: She and her network saved approximately 2,500 children by providing them with false identities—which she never disclosed despite torture and imprisonment by the Gestapo—and placing them with Polish families, keeping their true names in jars buried under an apple tree to reunite them with their families after the war.
motive: Sendler was motivated by the belief that "every child saved with my help is the justification of my existence on this Earth."

name: Stanislav Petrov
intro: Stanislav Petrov was an officer in the Soviet Air Defence Forces who is credited with single-handedly preventing nuclear armageddon.
description: Known as "the man who saved the world," in 1983, he correctly deduced that an alerting American intercontinental ballistic missile launch was a false alarm and refused to authorize a retaliatory strike that would have annihilated 50% of the American population and resulted in mutually assured destruction.
motive: Petrov was motivated by careful calculation of rational risk, the credible evidence available to him about Soviet early warning detection systems, and what he expressed as his civilian (as opposed to military) training.

name: Matthew Meselson
intro: Matthew Meselson is a renowned geneticist and molecular biologist who led the successful campaign to ban biological weapons in the United States.
description: His research and persistent lobbying convinced President Nixon to unilaterally renounce biological warfare in 1969, leading to the Biological Weapons Convention, which has since been signed by 185 nations to prevent the use of man-made plagues.
motive: Meselson was motivated by the scientific realization that biological weapons are uniquely uncontrollable, "repugnant and dishonorable," posing an existential threat to all of humanity.

name: Albertina Sisulu
intro: Albertina Sisulu was a South African nurse and anti-apartheid activist often referred to as "Ma Sisulu," the mother of the nation.
description: She led the 1956 Women's March of 20,000 women against pass laws and spent decades organizing underground resistance and providing medical care to the persecuted while enduring 25 years of banning orders and imprisonment.
motive: Sisulu was motivated by a vision of a non-racial democracy and an unwavering commitment to the dignity of Black South Africans under a regime of systemic oppression.

name: Septima Clark
intro: Septima Clark was an American educator and civil rights activist known as the "Grandmother of the Civil Rights Movement."
description: She developed the "Citizenship Schools" model that taught literacy to over 25,000 Black adults in the Deep South, enabling them to pass discriminatory voting tests and claim their right to political participation.
motive: Clark was motivated by the belief that "literacy is liberation" and that true social change could only occur when the most marginalized citizens were empowered to speak for themselves.

name: Eglantyne Jebb
intro: Eglantyne Jebb was a British social reformer who championed the fundamental human rights of children.
description: In 1919, she founded Save the Children, an NGO to relieve famine in post-war Austria-Hungary and Germany that has since benefited over 1 billion children with better health care and improved economic opportunities, and she also drafted the Declaration of the Rights of the Child (now a UN treaty).
motive: Jebb was motivated by moral outrage upon seeing photos of starving children suffering from her own government's post-war blockades, and she had been born into a family with a strong social conscience and commitment to public service.

name: Rick Rescorla
intro: Rick Rescorla was a decorated British-American army combat veteran beloved by his men and later director of security at Morgan Stanley during 9/11.
description: He was awarded silver and bronze stars for courageously leading an outnumbered platoon during the Vietnam War, and he is venerated for giving his life personally evacuating the WTC South Tower, making multiple trips and saving almost every one of his 2,700 employees after training them to prepare for this very scenario.
motive: Rescorla was motivated by a warrior's heart: in his last words to his wife, he said "...I have to get these people out safely. If something should happen to me, I want you to know I've never been happier."

name: John Rabe
intro: John Rabe was a German diplomat and businessman stationed in China who intervened during the Nanjing Massacre committed by invading Japanese forces.
description: He credibly saved 250,000 Chinese civilians from atrocities of rape, gamified torture, and execution by creating an international Nanjing safety zone and personally housing 650 refugees after the fall of the city, often directly intervening to stop Japanese soldiers from committing rape and murdering civilians.
motive: Rabe was motivated by a moral commitment: "there is a question of morality here… I cannot bring myself for now to betray the trust these people have put in me, and it is touching to see how they believe in me."

name: Witold Pilecki
intro: Witold Pilecki was a Polish cavalry officer and resistance leader who is the only known person to have volunteered to be imprisoned at the Auschwitz concentration camp.
description: During his two and a half years of voluntary captivity, he organized a secret resistance movement network of over 1,000 inmates, gathered intelligence on the Holocaust detailing the murders of thousands of victims per day that was smuggled to the Allies, and eventually staged a daring escape to provide firsthand evidence of Nazi atrocities.
motive: Pilecki was motivated by a profound sense of patriotic duty to Poland and a moral refusal to remain passive while his countrymen and Jewish citizens were being systematically murdered.

name: Sergey Preminin
intro: Sergey Preminin was a 19-year-old Soviet sailor and engine room technician serving aboard the nuclear submarine K-219 whose sacrifice averted a nuclear catastrophe when the ship suffered a catastrophic explosion in 1986.
description: With the cooling system failing and the ship on the verge of a nuclear meltdown, Preminin entered the reactor compartment in extreme heat and radiation to manually shut down the reactors, successfully preventing a nuclear disaster that could have released a fallout cloud threatening the lives of thousands of people along the American Eastern Seaboard at the cost of his own life.
motive: Preminin was motivated by a stoic sense of professional responsibility and the immediate, desperate need to protect his shipmates and the world from the consequences of a runaway nuclear reaction.

name: Smedley Butler
intro: Smedley Butler was a highly decorated Major General in the U.S. Marine Corps and a two-time Medal of Honor recipient who became a prominent anti-war activist.
description: His 1934 testimony before Congress successfully halted the "Business Plot," a fascist coup attempt by wealthy industrialists that sought to seize control of the U.S. government, overthrow President Franklin D. Roosevelt, and disenfranchise 130 million American citizens, and spent his later years writing War Is a Racket to criticize the exploitation of the military for corporate profit.
motive: Butler was motivated by a late-career disillusionment with imperialist warfare and a fierce loyalty to the rank-and-file soldiers whom he felt were being treated as "high-class muscle" for Wall Street.

name: Asa Jennings
intro: Asa Jennings was an American YMCA secretary and Methodist pastor who orchestrated one of the largest humanitarian rescues in history during the 1922 Burning of Smyrna in the Greco-Turkish War.
description: Despite having no military or diplomatic authority, he leveraged a combination of bluffing, bribery, and persistence to assemble a fleet of Italian and Greek merchant ships that secured the emergency evacuation of 350,000 Greek and Armenian refugees who were trapped against the sea and facing imminent massacre by advancing Ottoman forces.
motive: Jennings was motivated by a "muscular Christianity" and an unshakable conviction that he could not stand by and witness the total annihilation of a civilian population.

name: Jonas Salk
intro: Jonas Salk was an American virologist and medical researcher who developed the first successful inactivated polio vaccine during a period of national crisis and fear.
description: His refusal to patent the vaccine for immense personal wealth ensured its affordability and rapid global distribution, which has saved an estimated 1.5 million lives, prevented the permanent paralysis of over 18 million people worldwide, and led to the near-total eradication of a disease that had paralyzed or killed thousands of children annually.
motive: Salk was motivated by a humanitarian philosophy he called "biophilosophy," believing that the primary responsibility of a scientist is to use their knowledge to ensure the survival and well-being of future generations, not wealth ("could you patent the sun?").

name: Candy Lightner
intro: Candy Lightner is an American activist and the founder of Mothers Against Drunk Driving (MADD), which she established in 1980 after her 13-year-old daughter was killed by a repeat-offender drunk driver.
description: Her tireless advocacy led to the passage of over 700 new laws across the United States, including the federal mandate to raise the legal drinking age to 21, a shift credited with saving an estimated 25,000 lives and reducing alcohol-related traffic fatalities by 40% in the decades following.
motive: Lightner was motivated by a mother's grief transformed into furious resolve, refusing to accept the then-common cultural view that drunk driving deaths were merely accidents rather than preventable crimes, or what she described as "...the only socially acceptable form of homicide."

name: Abdul Ghaffar Khan
intro: Abdul Ghaffar Khan was a Pashtun leader and close ally of Mahatma Gandhi who founded the Khudai Khidmatgar, the world's first professional non-violent army.
description: He mobilized over 100,000 peaceful volunteers to resist colonial rule with non-violence, and his advocacy for education led to the establishment of numerous schools that reached thousands of children in the North-West Frontier Province.
motive: Khan was motivated by a profound belief that non-violence was the core of Islamic scripture and a desire to uplift his people through social reform and education rather than bloodshed ("...you are not aware of it. That weapon is patience and righteousness. No power on earth can stand against it.").

name: Janis Shinwari
intro: Janis Shinwari is an Afghan interpreter who served alongside United States military forces and later co-founded "No One Left Behind" to help fellow wartime allies.
description: He personally saved the lives of 5 American soldiers by grabbing a rifle during a single ambush by the Taliban and has since facilitated the resettlement of over 10,000 Afghan and Iraqi interpreters and their family members in the United States.
motive: Shinwari was motivated by a fierce sense of loyalty to the soldiers he served with and the conviction that the United States has a moral obligation to protect those who risked their lives in its service, saying "this is our responsibility that we should keep our promise."

name: Juan Pujol Garcia
intro: Juan Pujol Garcia, known by the codename "Garbo," was a Spanish double agent who played a pivotal role in the success of the D-Day landings during WWII.
description: Creating a massive network of 27 entirely imaginary sub-agents (called "Arabal") to feed the Nazis false intelligence, he deceived the German High Command into keeping fifteen divisions stationed away from Normandy in Pas-de-Calais, and he is credited with significantly reducing Allied casualties and shortening the war in Europe, potentially saving hundreds of thousands of lives.
motive: Garcia was motivated by a loathing of both political extremes of communism and fascism that he had developed after living through the Spanish Civil War as well as a desire to contribute something "for the good of humanity" by accelerating the downfall of the Nazi regime.

name: Dashrath Manjhi
intro: Dashrath Manjhi, known as the "Mountain Man," was a poor laborer in a remote Indian village who undertook a monumental task of manual engineering.
description: Using only a hammer and chisel, he worked for 22 years to carve a path 360 feet long through a solid mountain, reducing the distance to the nearest hospital from 43 miles to just 1 mile for thousands of villagers.
motive: Manjhi was motivated by the tragic death of his wife, who died because she could not receive timely medical care due to the mountain blocking the path, and a resolve that no other family should suffer the same fate—even in the face of doubt ("when I started hammering the hill, people called me a lunatic, but that steeled my resolve").

name: Sakena Yacoobi
intro: Sakena Yacoobi is an Afghan activist and educator who founded the Afghan Institute of Learning (AIL) to provide health and education services to women and children.
description: Under the first Taliban regime, she courageously operated 80 secret home schools for 3,000 girls, risking execution to ensure that a generation of women would not be denied the right to literacy and intellectual growth, and she has further provided education and health services to over 16 million people through AIL.
motive: Yacoobi was motivated by the belief that educating women is the only way to transform a society and break the cycle of poverty and violence that has plagued her nation.

name: Joe Darby
intro: Joe Darby is a former U.S. Army Reservist who was the whistleblower behind the exposure of prisoner abuse at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq.
description: Upon discovering CDs containing graphic photographs of soldiers torturing detainees, he handed the evidence to the Army's Criminal Investigation Command, an act that led to international outcry, immediate cessation of abuses against hundreds of detainees at the facility, and the criminal conviction of eleven soldiers and a total overhaul of military interrogation protocols.
motive: Darby was motivated by a strict personal moral code and a feeling of "violation" upon seeing the photos ("it violated everything I personally believed in and all I'd been taught about the rules of war").

name: Albert Göring
intro: Albert Göring was a German businessman and the younger brother of high-ranking Nazi leader Hermann Göring who used the protection of his family name to sabotage the Third Reich.
description: He saved between an estimated 1,000–1,500 Jews and political dissidents from certain death by securing their release from concentration camps to Switzerland through forged signatures and official requests, and he frequently sent trucks to camps demanding laborers, only to release the prisoners in the woods.
motive: Göring was motivated by a fundamental moral revulsion toward Nazism and a courageous commitment to using his proximity to power as a shield for the persecuted, despite his brother Hermann's position as Supreme Commander of the Luftwaffe (air force).

name: Júlio Lancellotti
intro: Júlio Lancellotti is a Brazilian Catholic priest and human rights defender who has dedicated his life to serving the homeless and marginalized populations of São Paulo.
description: He provides food, clothing, and legal advocacy to a community of over 35,000 homeless individuals, and his public campaigns—which include personally using a sledgehammer to destroy anti-homeless constructions such as boulders installed under city overpasses—have successfully forced the city to remove these forms of "hostile architecture" from dozens of public spaces despite being pepper-sprayed, spat on, and punched in the stomach by the São Paulo municipial guard.
motive: Lancellotti is motivated to fight what he calls "aporophobia," or fear and rejection of the poor, by "Liberation Theology," which emphasizes a "preferential option for the poor" and the belief that the dignity of the human person ("as the image and likeness of God") must always take precedence over urban aesthetics or property laws.

name: Silas Soule
intro: Silas Soule was a U.S. Army captain during the American Civil War who famously refused to participate in and ordered his men to stand down at the Sand Creek Massacre of 1864.
description: When his commanding officer ordered an attack on a peaceful village of Cheyenne and Arapaho, Soule ordered his company to hold their fire, saving the lives of his 100 soldiers from participating in a war crime, and later provided the testimony against his superiors that exposed the brutal slaughter of 230 Cheyenne and Arapaho civilians (including women and children) to the public.
motive: Soule was motivated by a steadfast sense of honor and a refusal to follow orders that he deemed cowardly ("any man who would take part in murders, knowing the circumstances as we did, was a low lived cowardly son of a bitch."), ultimately paying with his life when he was assassinated for his testimony.

name: Rick Hodes
intro: Rick Hodes is an American doctor who has spent over 35 years in Ethiopia serving as the medical director for the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, providing critical medical care free of charge.
description: He has personally treated over 2,500 patients with severe spinal tuberculosis and heart disease and has facilitated life-saving surgeries for hundreds of children by securing international funding and surgical teams, personally adopting 5 orphaned young patients into his own home to ensure they receive the complex, life-saving surgeries they need.
motive: Hodes is motivated by a deep religious and humanitarian faith, operating under the principle that if one has the skills to save a life, they have a direct responsibility to do so regardless of the cost, especially if no one else will ("I'm helping people that nobody else has any interest in. That's what keeps me going.").

name: Anuradha Koirala
intro: Anuradha Koirala is a Nepalese social activist who founded Maiti Nepal to combat the trafficking of women and children for sexual exploitation.
description: To date, she has led her organization in rescuing over 50,000 girls from forced prostitution and labor exploitation and established "transit homes" at the Indo-Nepal border to intercept traffickers and provide vocational training, ongoing rehabilitation, and medical care to 1,000 survivors annually.
motive: Koirala was motivated by the heartbreaking stories of survivors she met while teaching, leading her to believe that no child should ever be treated as a commodity.

name: Freweini Mebrahtu
intro: Freweini Mebrahtu is an Ethiopian chemical engineer who revolutionized menstrual health and education in her home country.
description: She designed and patented a high-quality, reusable menstrual pad and built a factory that produces 750,000 pads annually, which has helped over 800,000 girls in Ethiopia avoid missing school days and reduce drop-out rates in some regions by 50%.
motive: Mebrahtu was motivated by her own childhood memories of using rags for protection and a desire to ensure that biological realities never act as a barrier to a girl's right to an education.

name: Amy Wright
intro: Amy Wright is an American advocate for people with disabilities and the founder of Bitty & Beau's Coffee, named after her two children, a business that primarily employs individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
description: By expanding her business to dozens of locations, she has created a scalable model for inclusive employment for over 400 individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities across 23 locations that challenges societal perceptions and provides meaningful work to a demographic that faces an 80% unemployment rate.
motive: Wright is motivated by her own two children who have Down syndrome, and her goal is to create a world where people with disabilities are seen as valuable assets to the workforce rather than charity cases ("...trying to make people see the beauty in their lives that we see; I would not change you for the world, but I will change the world for you.”).

name: Carlo Urbani
intro: Carlo Urbani was an Italian physician and microbiologist who was the first to identify Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) as a new and dangerous infectious disease.
description: While working in Vietnam in 2003, he stayed on the front lines to treat patients, and his rapid warning to the WHO and the implementation of local quarantine protocols are credited with containing the outbreak to just 8,000 cases (tragically, including his own death), preventing a global pandemic that could have claimed millions of lives.
motive: Urbani was motivated by a lifelong commitment to Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders) and the belief that a doctor's place is always where the suffering is greatest, regardless of the personal risk ("if I cannot work in such situations, what am I here for?").

name: Giuseppe Moscati
intro: Giuseppe Moscati was an Italian doctor and professor of medicine known as the "Physician of the Poor" in early 20th-century Naples.
description: He was famous for treating approximately 3,000 patients free of charge every year and refusing payment from impoverished patients—often leaving money for them under their pillows instead—as well as for staying behind to evacuate an entire hospital before the roof collapsed during the 1906 eruption of Mount Vesuvius.
motive: Moscati was motivated by a synthesis of scientific excellence and Catholic piety, viewing the practice of medicine as a sacred mission to heal both the body and the spirit of the suffering ("How many suffering people you will more easily soothe by advising and going straight to their souls, instead of giving good prescriptions to be given to the chemist!").

name: Denis Mukwege
intro: Denis Mukwege is a Congolese gynecologist and Nobel Peace Prize laureate who founded Panzi Hospital to treat survivors of wartime sexual violence.
description: He has performed reconstructive surgeries on over 50,000 survivors of wartime sexual violence, such as gang rape, and provides holistic psychological and legal support to 3,000 new victims every year, becoming a global voice calling for an end to the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war, despite surviving multiple assassination attempts.
motive: Mukwege is motivated by the resilience of the women he treats and a conviction that "justice is everyone's business," refusing to remain silent about atrocities committed in his country.

name: Lois Gibbs
intro: Lois Gibbs is an American environmental activist who led her community's fight against toxic waste at Love Canal in Niagara Falls, New York.
description: A stay-at-home mother with no prior political experience, she organized her neighbors to prove that their children's illnesses were caused by 21,000 tons of buried chemicals, successfully lobbying for the evacuation of 800 families from their contaminated homes and inspiring the federal "Superfund" program, which has since funded the cleanup of thousands of toxic sites affecting millions of Americans.
motive: Gibbs was motivated by maternal anger and the realization that the government and chemical companies were willing to prioritize corporate liability over the lives of her children.

name: Jamila Afghani
intro: Jamila Afghani is an Afghan peace activist and feminist who works to promote women's rights through the lens of Islamic education.
description: She created a groundbreaking gender-sensitive curriculum for imams, training over 6,000 imams to advocate against domestic violence and for a woman's right to education and inheritance in their sermons, and her literacy programs have directly educated over 50,000 women across Afghanistan.
motive: Afghani is motivated by the belief that true social change must come from within a culture's religious and social framework ("to truly have sustainable peace in Afghanistan or anywhere, we need to educate and empower women.").

name: Padre Alejandro Solalinde
intro: Alejandro Solalinde is a Mexican Catholic priest and human rights activist who runs the "Hermanos en el Camino" shelter for migrants.
description: His shelter provides safety, food, and medical aid to over 20,000 Central American migrants each year, protecting them from the drug cartels and corrupt officials who seek to kidnap, extort, or kill them.
motive: Solalinde is motivated by the "migrant Christ," believing that the way a society treats the most vulnerable traveler is the ultimate test of its moral and spiritual health ("I think people are the most important thing in this world—not money or material goods. Everything should be at the service of people.").

name: Rami Elhanan
intro: Rami Elhanan is an Israeli graphic designer and peace activist who became a member of the Parents Circle-Families Forum after his 14-year-old daughter was killed by a suicide bomber.
description: Instead of seeking revenge, he partnered with Bassam Aramin, a Palestinian father who also lost a daughter, and a joint network of 600 grieving families to prevent further retaliatory violence by traveling the world promoting dialogue and reconciliation between Israelis and Palestinians and sharing his story of reconciliation with over 100,000 students and civilians in Israel and Palestine.
motive: Elhanan is motivated by the belief that the cycle of violence can only be broken by "harnessing the power of grief" to foster empathy and humanize the "other" on both sides of the conflict.

name: Aki Ra
intro: Aki Ra is a Cambodian museum curator who has dedicated his life to clearing the landmines he was once forced to plant as a conscripted child soldier and supporting child victims of landmines.
description: He has personally defused and removed over 50,000 landmines and unexploded ordnances using basic hand tools, and he founded the Cambodia Landmine Museum to provide education and housing for dozens of child victims of explosions.
motive: Aki Ra is motivated by a deep sense of personal atonement and a mission to make his country safe for future generations after having himself been orphaned and conscripted by the Khmer Rouge, .

name: James Harrison
intro: James Harrison was an Australian man with a unique blood antibody, Anti-D, who was a lifelong plasma donor.
description: His decision to donate blood plasma every two weeks from the age of 18 to 81 saved the lives of 2 million babies from a deadly blood disorder called Hemolytic Disease of the Fetus and Newborn (HDFN).
motive: Harrison is motivated by a desire to give back, having pledged to begin donating blood at the age of 14 after receiving a massive transfusion for a chest surgery, and according to his daughter, "He always said it does not hurt, and the life you save could be your own."

name: Fazle Hasan Abed
intro: Fazle Hasan Abed was the founder of the Bangladesh Rehabilitation Assistance Committee (BRAC), which grew from a small relief operation into the largest non-governmental organization in the world.
description: His programs in microfinance, healthcare, and education have reached over 100 million people in Asia and Africa, contributing significantly to reducing Bangladesh's child mortality rate by over 70%.
motive: Abed was motivated by the conviction that poverty is a systemic deprivation of human rights and that the poor, if given the right tools and agency, can lead their own development ("Education is the most important development intervention that one can make to a human life").

name: Frances Oldham Kelsey
intro: Frances Oldham Kelsey was a Canadian-American pharmacologist and physician for the FDA who famously blocked the approval of the toxic drug thalidomide which had been prescribed in Europe for morning sickness.
description: Despite intense pressure from a major pharmaceutical company, her refusal to authorize the drug without more safety data prevented an estimated 10,000 to 20,000 cases of debilitating birth defects in the United States.
motive: Kelsey was motivated by a rigorous commitment to scientific integrity and the belief that a regulator's primary duty is to protect public safety from corporate haste.

name: Stan Brock
intro: Stan Brock was a British philanthropist, presenter, actor and author who founded the charity Remote Area Medical (RAM) in 1985.
description: RAM has operated more than 1,000 free clinics and provided more than $150 million in charitable care, saving the lives of millions of uninsured Americans; Brock had no money, no income, and no bank account, sleeping at a small RAM headquarters and spending 365 days a year at charity events.
motive: Brock was motivated to first establish the organization after being unable to gain access to healthcare when he suffered a serious injury in Guyana and realizing that this problem was not unique to developing countries.

name: Gladys Aylward
intro: Gladys Aylward was a British domestic servant turned missionary who became a legendary figure in China, known as the "Virtuous One," for her work with orphans and her service as a government-appointed "foot inspector" to prevent the painful practice of footbinding.
description: During the Japanese invasion in 1938, she led 100 orphans on a perilous 27-day journey over mountains to reach safety, despite being wounded herself and having no military escort or supplies.
motive: Aylward was motivated by an indomitable religious faith and a deep sense of justice, notably using her official role to advocate for the rights of women and successfully ending the ancient, painful practice of foot-binding in the region under her care.

name: Antoinette Tuff
intro: Antoinette Tuff was a bookkeeper who worked at a Georgia elementary school and convinced an armed 20-year-old shooter suffering from serious mental health issues to surrender himself to police.
description: She shared her heartbreaking personal testimony of struggles she had recently endured—the collapse of a 26-year marriage due to her husband's infidelity and her subsequent attempts to commit suicide—to reassure the assailant and deescalate the situation, saving the lives of nearly 800 students and staff members without a single shot being fired by the gunman.
motive: Tuff was motivated by an unshakeable sense of spiritual purpose and radical empathy, believing that her own life's hardships had uniquely prepared her to recognize and soothe the pain of another person on the brink of disaster.

name: Rosemary West
intro: Rosemary West is a British serial killer who, along with her husband Fred West, perpetrated a series of sadistic sexual assaults and murders in Gloucester.
description: She was convicted of the torture and murder of 10 young women and girls, including her own daughter and stepdaughter, whose remains were discovered buried beneath the family home.
motive: West was motivated by a shared pathological sexual sadism and a complete lack of empathy, later described as having taken an undisputedly leading role in the predatory entrapment of her victims.

name: Silvia Meraz
intro: Silvia Meraz is a Mexican serial killer and cult leader who led a small group in Nacozari, Sonora, that practiced human sacrifice.
description: Between 2009 and 2012, she ritualistically murdered and dismembered three people, including two ten-year-old boys, as blood sacrifices on an altar to "Santa Muerte" in exchange for supernatural protection and wealth.
motive: Meraz was motivated by a fanatical religious delusion and the belief that blood sacrifices were a necessary currency for divine favor.

name: Pauline Nyiramasuhuko
intro: Pauline Nyiramasuhuko was a Rwandan politician who served as the Minister for Family Welfare and Women's Development and incited crimes against humanity during the 1994 Rwandan Genocide.
description: She was the first woman to be convicted of genocide by an international tribunal for her role in orchestrating the abduction and systematic rape of thousands of Tutsi women ("before you kill the women, you need to rape them"), many of whom were burned alive, and the massacre of refugees who she intentionally trapped at humanitarian aid sites.
motive: Nyiramasuhuko was motivated by an extremist Hutu Power ideology and a ruthless desire to maintain political dominance through the total dehumanization of the Tutsi minority.

name: Hermine Braunsteiner
intro: Hermine Braunsteiner was a female guard at the Majdanek and Ravensbrück concentration camps, known to prisoners as "The Stomping Mare."
description: She was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of women, elderly people, and children, whom she frequently kicked to death with steel-studded boots or personally dragged by their hair to the gas chambers during the Holocaust.
motive: Braunsteiner was motivated by a sadistic enjoyment of authority and an internalized Nazi racial hierarchy that viewed her victims as sub-human.

name: Georgia Tann
intro: Georgia Tann was an American child trafficker who ran the Tennessee Children's Home Society, masquerading as a legitimate adoption agent.
description: Over two decades, she kidnapped and sold an estimated 5,000 children from mostly poor, single mothers to wealthy families, while neglect and abuse in her care resulted in the deaths of over 500 infants.
motive: Tann was motivated by immense financial greed and a narcissistic belief that she was "improving" the children's lives by removing them from poor biological parents.

name: Hissène Habré
intro: Hissène Habré was the dictator of Chad from 1982 to 1990, whose regime was characterized by widespread state-sponsored terror.
description: Called "the African Pinochet" (after the ruthless Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet), he was convicted of crimes against humanity for the political murder of over 40,000 people, the systematic torture of tens of thousands of others through his brutal secret police force, the Documentation and Security Directorate, massacres of ethnic minorities, and mass rape and sexual enslavement.
motive: Habré was motivated by a paranoid obsession with consolidating power and the use of extreme violence as a tool to suppress ethnic and political opposition.

name: Marcel Petiot
intro: Marcel Petiot was a French doctor and serial killer who operated in occupied Paris during World War II.
description: He lured an estimated 60 Jewish refugees and resistance fighters to his home with promises of escape from the Nazis to South America, only to poison them with cyanide and steal their belongings, leaving their remains in a basement furnace.
motive: Petiot was motivated by opportunism and a sociopathic desire to profit from the desperation of those fleeing for their lives.

name: Lavrentiy Beria
intro: Lavrentiy Beria was a Soviet politician and head of Stalin's ruthless secret police, the NKVD.
description: He led the Katyn Massacre of 22,000 Polish officers during the Soviet occupation of WWII, deported millions of ethnic minorities to Siberia and gulag camps, and infamously had his staff kidnap hundreds of young teenage girls he saw on the streets of Moscow over many years for him to rape in his soundproofed office under threat of imprisonment (or false promises of releasing their imprisoned loved ones) if they refused—his victims were sometimes murdered and buried naked in his wife's rose garden.
motive: Beria was motivated by political ambition and a desire to eventually replace Stalin as the sole dictator of the Soviet Union by any means necessary as well as predatory sexual proclivities enabled by his high position.

name: Jeronimus Cornelisz
intro: Jeronimus Cornelisz was a Dutch apothecary and Dutch East India Company merchant who seized control of the survivors of the Batavia shipwreck in 1629 and led one of the bloodiest mutinies in history.
description: In a reign of terror on a desert island, he and his followers systematically murdered and sexually enslaved 125 men, women, and children who were of lower social status through stabbing, strangulation, and drowning to conserve supplies and ensure total obedience.
motive: Cornelisz was motivated by a nihilistic ego and a twisted interpretation of Epicurean philosophy, believing that as a "superior being," he was incapable of committing a sin, and he was likely psychopathic as well as mentally compromised from syphillis.

name: Thomas Thistlewood
intro: Thomas Thistlewood was a British plantation overseer in colonial Jamaica who kept a meticulous diary of his atrocities.
description: Over his career, he recorded thousands of acts of brutal physical torture and 3,852 recorded rapes of at least 138 enslaved women, including the invention of the "Derby's Dose," whereby a slave would be flogged, have lime juice, salt pickle, and bird pepper rubbed into their wounds, and then forced to experience having a fellow slave defecate into their mouth.
motive: Thistlewood was motivated by a desire to maintain absolute psychological and physical control over his labor force through a systematic regime of terror and dehumanization.

name: Gilles de Rais
intro: Gilles de Rais was a French knight and companion-in-arms to Joan of Arc who later became one of history's most prolific child killers.
description: He was convicted of the abduction, ritualistic torture, rape, and murder of an estimated 80 to 200 children, mostly young boys, whom he lured to his various castles.
motive: de Rais was motivated by a complex mix of sexual sadism and an occult-driven belief that sacrificing children would help him regain his squandered fortune through alchemy and the summoning of demons.

name: Fritz Haarmann
intro: Fritz Haarmann, known as the "Vampire of Hanover," was a German serial killer who terrorized the Weimar Republic between 1918 and 1924.
description: He murdered at least 24 young men and boys by biting through their throats during sexual assault, and he was rumored to have sold their processed remains as black-market meat.
motive: Haarmann was motivated by a violent sexual obsession and a predatory instinct that thrived in the social chaos of post-WWI Germany.

name: Michael Swango
intro: Michael Swango is a former American physician and serial killer who abused his medical credentials to poison those under his care.
description: Although he only admitted to 4 murders, he is suspected of having lethally poisoned up to 60 patients and colleagues across various hospitals in the United States and Zimbabwe by administering fatal doses of arsenic or potassium chloride.
motive: Swango was motivated by a lifelong obsession with death and a narcissistic thrill derived from the power to decide who lived or died while disguised as a healer.

name: Miyuki Ishikawa
intro: Miyuki Ishikawa was a respected Japanese midwife and hospital director who became the most prolific serial killer in Japanese history during the post-WWII era.
description: Operating with the help of her husband and a doctor, she is believed to have murdered up to 169 infants through intentional neglect in what came to be called the Kotobuki San'in incident, while simultaneously extorting large sums of money from the grieving parents under the guise that his "services" were a mercy.
motive: Ishikawa was motivated by a cold, utilitarian view of human life, believing that the infants who were often born into extreme poverty were better off dead and that her actions were a pragmatic solution to Japan's post-war population crisis.

name: Mengistu Haile Mariam
intro: Mengistu Haile Mariam was the leader of the "Derg" (or "committee"), the military junta that ruled Ethiopia following the overthrow of the monarchy.
description: His "Red Terror" campaign resulted in the deaths of an estimated 500,000 to 750,000 people through mass executions, systematic torture, and the weaponization of famine against his own population.
motive: Mariam was motivated by a militant Marxist-Leninist ideology and a totalitarian impulse to purge any real or perceived opposition to his absolute rule.

name: Francisco Macías Nguema
intro: Francisco Macías Nguema was the first President of Equatorial Guinea, whose reign turned the country into a "concentration camp" internationally known as the "Dachau of Africa"
description: He presided over the execution or forced exile of up to 80,000 people, over one-third of the population, specifically targeting intellectuals and the "educated" to ensure no one could challenge his authority.
motive: Nguema was motivated by a growing mental instability and a xenophobic, paranoid obsession with power that led him to declare himself a god while dismantling the nation's infrastructure.

name: Lothar von Trotha
intro: Lothar von Trotha was a German military commander who led the colonial forces in German South West Africa (now Namibia).
description: In 1904, he issued an extermination order against the Herero and Nama people, leading to the deaths of over 65,000 Herero and 10,000 Nama through genocide or by driving them into the desert to die of thirst.
motive: von Trotha was motivated by an extreme social Darwinism and a belief that "unruly" indigenous populations had to be physically annihilated to make room for German expansion.

name: Salvatore Riina
intro: Salvatore "Toto" Riina was the boss of the "Cosa Nostra" (Sicilian Mafia) who launched a bloody war against the Italian state.
description: He personally committed or ordered the murders of over 1,000 people, including high-profile judges, rival gangsters, and even the 13-year-old son of a turncoat who was strangled and dissolved in acid.
motive: Riina was motivated by a sociopathic drive for total dominance over the mafia and the belief that absolute brutality was the only way to silence his enemies.

name: Biljana Plavšić
intro: Biljana Plavšić was a Bosnian Serb politician and university professor who served as President of Republika Srpska during the Bosnian War.
description: She was convicted of crimes against humanity for her role in the ethnic cleansing of tens of thousands of Bosniaks and Croats, famously stating that the process of purging non-Serbs was a "natural phenomenon."
motive: Plavšić was motivated by a fervent ethnic nationalism and a pseudo-scientific belief in the biological superiority of the Serbian people.

name: Jennifer Wenisch
intro: Jennifer Wenisch is a German citizen who defected to the Islamic State and who was convicted for her role in the enslavement and death of a Yazidi girl.
description: She regularly ordered her ISIS husband to abuse the Yazidi mother and daughter they had enslaved, and she stood by while her husband chained the 5-year-old daughter outside in 122°F heat as punishment for wetting the bed, allowing the child to die of thirst while threatening the mother with a firearm.
motive: Wenisch was motivated by an extremist religious ideology and a callous indifference to human suffering that viewed non-believers as mere property.

name: David Berg
intro: David Berg was the founder and leader of the "Children of God" (later The Family International) cult, which he controlled for decades through sexual abuse.
description: He institutionalized the sexual abuse of thousands of children within the cult by mandating a "Law of Love" that eliminated sexual taboos and encouraged "Flirty Fishing" by female cult members to recruit men into the organization by providing them sexual favors.
motive: Berg was motivated by a messianic god complex and a predatory desire to use religious dogma as a justification for his own sexual deviancy and control over others.

name: Roch Thériault
intro: Roch Thériault was the leader of a small Canadian cult known as the Ant Hill Kids, where he exerted total psychological and physical control over his followers.
description: Calling himself Moses, he subjected his 34 followers and their children to sexual and physical abuse as well as horrific ritualistic mutilations such as ejaculating onto the exposed brain of a woman he had murdered and performing amateur surgeries that resulted in the agonizing deaths of several members and infants.
motive: Thériault was motivated by a delusion that he was a prophet of God and a sadistic need to break the bodies and spirits of his followers to prove his divinity.

name: Farid Fata
intro: Farid Fata is a former oncologist who once owned Michigan Hematology-Oncology (MHO), one of the largest cancer practices in Michigan, and who intentionally misdiagnosed healthy people with cancer to profit from expensive treatments.
description: He administered over 9,000 unnecessary injections of toxic chemotherapy to 553 patients, many of whom were healthy and subsequently suffered permanent organ damage, tooth loss, and psychological trauma from believing they were dying.
motive: Fata was motivated by immeasurable financial greed, defrauding Medicare and private insurers of $17 million to fund a lavish lifestyle at the expense of his patients' lives.

name: Anatoly Slivko
intro: Anatoly Slivko was a Soviet serial killer and highly respected youth club leader with the USSR Young Pioneers program for adolescents who hid his crimes behind the disguise of mentorship.
description: He tortured and murdered seven boys between 1964 and 1985, filming his victims as he hanged them and then performed various "experiments" on their bodies to satisfy his sexual fetishes.
motive: Slivko was motivated by a pedophilic necrophilia: his routine of hanging, mutilation and burning his victims was an attempt to recreate a traffic accident involving the violent death of a teenage boy dressed in a Young Pioneers uniform that he had witnessed in 1961 and which had sexually aroused him.

name: Robert Berdella
intro: Robert Berdella, known as the "Kansas City Butcher," was an American serial killer who abducted and tortured young men in his home.
description: He murdered at least six men after subjecting them to days of horrific physical, sexual and psychological torture, documenting his "experiments" in detailed logs and photographs before dismembering their bodies.
motive: Bardella was motivated by a desire for absolute power over another human being, a cold, clinical fascination with the process of human suffering and death, and fantasies he developed from watching the film adaptation of John Fowles' The Collector.

name: Jean-Luc Brunel
intro: Jean-Luc Brunel was a French modeling agent and close associate of Jeffrey Epstein who was a central figure in an international sex trafficking ring.
description: He was accused of scouting and procuring over 1,000 girls and young women for sexual abuse by powerful men (including himself), often using the promise of modeling careers as bait for the vulnerable.
motive: Brunel was motivated by the pursuit of social influence among global elites and a predatory entitlement that viewed young women as disposable commodities for trade.

name: James Grigson
intro: James Grigson was a Texas forensic psychiatrist nicknamed "Dr. Death" for his testimony in capital punishment cases.
description: He testified in over 160 cases, almost always asserting with "100% certainty" that the defendant would kill again, a practice that led to the execution of dozens of individuals, some of whom were later proven innocent or mentally incompetent.
motive: Grigson was motivated by a narcissistic overconfidence in his own diagnostic abilities and a willingness to provide the state with "expert" justifications for the death penalty regardless of scientific validity.

name: Kaing Guek Eav
intro: Kang Kek Iew, known as "Comrade Duch," was a Cambodian official who headed the notorious Security Prison 21 under the Khmer Rouge.
description: He oversaw the systematic torture and execution of over 18,000 "enemies of the state" including women and children, meticulously documenting the forced confessions of every victim before they were bludgeoned to death in the Killing Fields.
motive: Eav was motivated by a bureaucratic zeal for order and a fanatical loyalty to the Khmer Rouge's agrarian-communist revolution, which demanded the total elimination of dissent.

name: Shoko Asahara
intro: Shoko Asahara was the founder of the violent Aum Shinrikyo doomsday cult in Japan, which he led to commit indiscriminate terrorist attacks on the populace as well as targeted murders.
description: In 1995, he unleashed the deadliest domestic terror act in Japanese history when he ordered the sarin gas attack on the Tokyo subway that killed 14 people and injured over 5,800 others, following years of smaller-scale assassinations and biological terror attempts.
motive: Asahara was motivated by a paranoid delusion that he had met and been divinely entrusted by the Hindu deity Shiva and the belief that he could trigger a global armageddon that would leave his followers as the sole survivors.

name: Robert Hadden
intro: Robert Hadden is a former gynecologist who used his medical position at prestigious New York hospitals to sexually abuse his patients for over two decades.
description: He was convicted of the predatory sexual abuse of at least 576 women, including those who were pregnant or seeking treatment for serious medical conditions, and underage girls.
motive: Hadden was motivated by a predatory sense of entitlement and a belief that his status as an esteemed physician made him untouchable and his victims' voices irrelevant.

name: David Parker Ray
intro: David Parker Ray, known as the "Toy-Box Killer," was an American kidnapper and serial killer who built a $100,000 soundproof torture chamber in a semi-trailer he called his "tox box."
description: He is suspected of murdering up to 60 women whom he abducted, drugged, and subjected to weeks of sexual torture using elaborate mechanical devices while playing them an audio tape explaining their new "reality."
motive: Ray was motivated by a sexual sadism for raping, torturing, and even murdering womenm which began in his adolescence, and a clinical desire to exert total, god-like control over his victims' every physical and psychological experience.

name: Josef Fritzl
intro: Josef Fritzl is an Austrian man who held his own daughter captive as a sex slave in a soundproof basement for 24 years.
description: During her decades of imprisonment, he raped her thousands of times, fathering seven children with her—one of whom died in infancy due to his refusal to seek medical care—while lying to the community that she had run away to join a cult.
motive: Fritzl was motivated by a pathologically narcissistic desire for absolute domestic control arising from a severe combined personality disorder and addiction to a fantasy of sexual enslavement, for which he has showed no remorse ("just look into the cellars of other people, you might find other families and girls down there.").

name: Gerard John Schaefer
intro: Gerard John Schaefer was an American police officer and serial killer known as the "Killer Cop" who utilized his uniform to abduct young women in Florida.
description: He is believed to have murdered up to 30 women and girls, whom he frequently took to remote areas to torture and hang from trees, often returning to the crime scenes to engage in necrophilia.
motive: Schaefer was motivated by a violent sexual sadism and the thrill of using his position of public trust as a weapon of predatory deception.

name: Karla Homolka
intro: Karla Homolka is a Canadian serial killer who, along with her husband Paul Bernardo, kidnapped, raped, and murdered three young women.
description: She was directly involved in the drugging and sexual assault of her victims—including her own 15-year-old sister—and helped film the horrific crimes to satisfy her husband's fantasies and maintain their "bond."
motive: Homolka was motivated by a toxic, dependent relationship with Bernardo and a sociopathic willingness to participate in lethal violence to preserve her domestic life.

name: Leonard Lake
intro: Leonard Lake operated a survivalist bunker with his accomplice, Charles Ng, in the Sierra Nevada foothills designed for sexual slavery.
description: Along with his accomplice, he filmed themself torturing and murdering at least 11 to 25 people, including entire families and infants, whom the two viewed as "assets" for a post-apocalyptic world.
motive: Lake and Ng were motivated by a shared misanthropic philosophy and a sadistic desire to live out "Operation Shipmate," a fantasy of total sexual and physical enslavement of others, and Lake had long been fascinated with the idea of holding women captive after reading the John Fowles' novel The Collector (1963) in his teens.

name: Luis Garavito
intro: Luis Garavito, known as "The Beast," was a Colombian serial killer and pedophile who is the most prolific murderer in modern history.
description: He confessed to the abduction, torture, and murder of 140 boys, though the actual number of victims across Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela is estimated to be over 300.
motive: Garavito was motivated by a predatory sexual desire for "innocent"-looking children with "cute faces" and a resentment toward society, given his troubled upbringing and own childhood experiences of sexual abuse, often targeting impoverished children who would not be immediately missed.

name: Jean-Bédel Bokassa
intro: Jean-Bédel Bokassa was the military dictator and later self-proclaimed Emperor of the Central African Empire.
description: His regime was marked by extreme brutality, including the 1979 massacre of 100 schoolchildren who were beaten to death for protesting the high cost of mandatory uniforms made by a factory owned by his wife.
motive: Bokassa was motivated by an absurdly lavish megalomania and a desire to emulate Napoleon Bonaparte, prioritizing his own ceremonial vanity over the lives of his citizens.

name: Keith Hunter Jesperson
intro: Keith Hunter Jesperson, known as the "Happy Face Killer," was a Canadian-American serial killer who murdered women across the United States.
description: He confessed to murdering eight women while working as a long-haul truck driver, often strangling his victims and leaving "happy face" notes for the media when he felt he was not receiving enough credit for his crimes.
motive: Jesperson was motivated by a desire for notoriety and a predatory thrill derived from the anonymity and mobility afforded by his profession.

name: Fred Zain
intro: Fred Zain was a forensic lab technician for the West Virginia and Bexar County, Texas, state police who systematically falsified evidence.
description: His perjured testimony and fabricated blood-test results led to the wrongful conviction of over 180 people, some of whom spent over a decade in prison for crimes they did not commit.
motive: Zain was motivated by a desire to please prosecutors and maintain an inflated reputation as a "star witness," regardless of the scientific truth or devastating human consequences for defendants.

name: Walter Jackson Freeman II
intro: Walter Jackson Freeman II was an American physician who popularized the pseudoscientific "transorbital lobotomy" as a supposed treatment for mental illness.
description: He personally performed nearly 3,500 lobotomies using an ice pick inserted through the eye socket, often in assembly-line fashion, leaving thousands of patients—including Rosemary Kennedy—permanently, catastrophically brain-damaged or in a vegetative state.
motive: Jackson was motivated by a reckless "medical crusader" complex and a desire for fame, sometimes performing "show" lobotomies with his non-dominant hand on real patients, believing that a quick surgical fix was superior to long-term psychiatric care.

name: Ion Ficior
intro: Ion Ficior was a Romanian communist labor camp commander who ran the brutal Periprava forced labor camp, known as a "death camp," during the 1950s and 60s.
description: He was convicted of crimes against humanity for the deaths of 103 political prisoners who perished under his command due to starvation, lack of medical care, and systematic beatings.
motive: Ficior was motivated by a zealous adherence to Stalinist ideology and a sadistic commitment to "re-educating" those who opposed the communist regime through physical destruction.

name: Shirō Ishii
intro: Shirō Ishii was the commander of Unit 731, a covert biological and chemical warfare research unit of the Imperial Japanese Army that committed atrocious crimes against humanity.
description: His activities resulted in up to 300,000 total deaths from biological warfare, and he oversaw the live vivisection and lethal experimentation of an estimated 14,000 civilians and POWs at Unit 731, including infecting women and children with the plague, amputating limbs, and exposing them to extreme pressure, frostbite, and toxic chemical agents.
motive: Ishii was motivated by a fanatical nationalism and a cold, scientific curiosity that viewed human beings as "maruta" (logs) and bacteria as pets for the advancement of Japan's military capabilities.

name: Niels Högel
intro: Niels Högel is a German former nurse who is considered the most prolific serial killer in the country's post-war history.
description: He was convicted of murdering 85 patients—though investigators believe the true number may be closer to 300—by injecting them with lethal doses of cardiovascular medication to induce cardiac arrest.
motive: Högel was motivated by a desire to demonstrate his resuscitation skills and gain the admiration of his colleagues by "saving" the very patients he had intentionally poisoned, earning the nickname "Resuscitation Rambo."

name: Lawrence Sigmund Bittaker
intro: Lawrence Bittaker, known alongside his partner Roy Norris as the "Tool-Box Killers," was an American serial killer who targeted teenage girls in California.
description: Together with his accomplice, he abducted, raped, and murdered five girls using household tools such as pliers and ice picks, audio-recording the torture of their victims to relive the crimes later.
motive: Bittaker was motivated by a highly organized sexual sadism and a predatory desire to inflict the maximum possible physical and psychological pain before killing his victims.

name: Gertrude Baniszewski
intro: Gertrude Baniszewski was an American housewife who presided over the prolonged torture and murder of 16-year-old Sylvia Likens.
description: With the help of her own children and neighborhood youths, she subjected Likens to three months of horrific beatings, burns, sexual humiliation, dehydration, and starvation until the girl died from her injuries.
motive: Baniszewski was motivated by a displaced resentment for her own failing health and poverty, using Likens as a scapegoat to exert a cruel and arbitrary power over a vulnerable dependent out of jealousy.

name: Paolo Macchiarini
intro: Paolo Macchiarini is an Italian thoracic surgeon and former researcher convicted of scientific misconduct who became famous for fraudulently pioneering a completely useless plastic windpipe implant seeded with stem cells.
description: He performed these experimental surgeries on eight patients despite knowing the synthetic organs were failing, leading to the agonizingly painful deaths of seven people and permanent injury to the eighth, as well as the discovery that he had falsified data in numerous high-profile medical journals.
motive: Macchiarini was motivated by a narcissistic pursuit of scientific fame and a willingness to commit research fraud, treating human patients like lab rats, to maintain his image as a medical visionary at the expense of human life.

name: General Butt Naked
intro: Joshua Milton Blahyi, known as General Butt Naked, was a Liberian warlord during the country's first civil war.
description: He admitted to being responsible for the deaths of more than 20,000 people and frequently led his child soldiers, "Small Boy Unit," into battle naked, practicing human sacrifice and cannibalism of children to gain spiritual protection.
motive: Blahyi was motivated by a fanatical belief in the power of juju (witchcraft) and a desire to project an aura of supernatural invincibility, showing his conscripts Jean-Claude Van Damme films and "that killing people was a game" in an effort to "uproot the fear of death."

name: Oskar Dirlewanger
intro: Oskar Dirlewanger was the commander of the SS-Sturmbrigade Dirlewanger, a unit composed of convicted criminals during WWII.
description: His unit was responsible for the massacre of over 150,000 civilians in Poland and Belarus, often rounding people into barns and burning them alive or engaging in mass sexual violence and looting, and he himself kept numerous women as sex slaves, murdered children in orphanages, and took pleasure in watching Jewish girls he had injected with poison writhe in agony before boiling their corpses into soap.
motive: Dirlewanger was motivated by mental instability and a depraved sexual sadism further fueled by alcoholism as well as a belief that the "total war" of the Eastern Front provided a legitimate outlet for his personal violent and predatory impulses.

name: Eugene de Kock
intro: Eugene de Kock, known as "Prime Evil," was a South African police colonel and assassin under the apartheid government.
description: He commanded the Vlakplaas unit, which was responsible for the abduction, torture, and murder of dozens of anti-apartheid activists, whose bodies were often blown up with landmines to destroy evidence.
motive: de Kock was motivated by a fanatical defense of white minority rule and a cold, professional commitment to utilizing state-sanctioned terror to maintain the apartheid system.

name: Enriqueta Martí
intro: Enriqueta Martí, known as the "Vampire of Barcelona," was a Spanish serial killer, procuress, and occultist who preyed on the city's most vulnerable children in the early 20th century.
description: She kidnapped dozens of children to be used in her various "businesses," which included operating a secret pedophile brothel for the wealthy and murdering victims to extract their blood, fat, and bone marrow for the production of expensive "miracle" ointments and youth elixirs.
motive: Martí was motivated by a cold-blooded pursuit of wealth and social status, exploiting the superstitions of the elite by turning human suffering into a high-priced commodity for the black market, as well as mental disorders.
